captions.text:
I've been a blacksmith armer for over
thirty years. I've created weapons for
over two hundred feature films.
This is Man at Arms.
I purchased the toy from the toy shop just to match up.
I'm making a real weapon and it's proportional to a man's hand as opposed to a child's hand
that the toy sword was made to. So I scaled it up a bit.

Thundercats Sword of Omens was one of
the most requested weapons from the fans.
I had Alicia cut out

the thunder cats emblem out of eighteen
gauge mild steel. I'm going to dome that

afterwards to match the contour of the
glass gemstone.

The grip consists of seven different
elements that are stacked together like

a palm tree. I use duplo Lego type
blocks to build a custom old frame and

then use room temperature rubber
molding compound

I use the duplo blocks because i can
build a mold frame of whatever shape I want,
and it goes together relatively quickly.

so we've made one mold than we cast the
seven pieces screw those or attach those

to like a wax tree and then i'll be
pouring investment which is like plaster

of Paris over the top. When I melt the
wax out of their it'll leave a cavity

and I'll be able to poured molten bronze
into that cavity

and it'll take on the shape of the
original one that I made.

I've cut out the three sixteenths thick
individual components for the hilt on

the Sword of Omens and now we're adding
the bevels and cleaning up the exterior

of the bezel that holds the stone and
the spike that comes off the front
The burnout oven as its name implies
burns out the wax leaving that cavity heat up molten bronze
Imagine a river of molten magma

pouring over the top of this mold, and
that's what it is right now.

Investment casting as I call it is also
known as lost wax casting

because when i give the wax model the
investment
actually disappears finished when I'm finished with it. The mold actually breaks apart.
So it's only one-time use.

The groove down the center of the place
is called a fuller, so I heated up the

blade in the forge, brought it over to
fly press and squeezed in a fuller.

People used to call it a blood groove
the myth is that if you stick it in the
body with a fuller or blood groove in it,

it releases the vacuum so you can clear
sort out the body. It's not that at all.

The fuller lightens the blade and adds
more rigidity for strength on the blade.
After I fullered the blade using the fly press, I took it to a turbine belt grinder

so I could grind the
fullers. After that was done I went back
over to my regular belt grinder and browned the hollow grinds with
a ten inch contact wheel.
After i got the initial bevels on the belt grinder,
I put all the pieces together to see how it looked.
And i'm pretty happy with how it's coming together.

Now I'm cutting the Eye of Thundara from
a block of red glass.
I use a water-cooled diamond core drill
I took it to progressively finer wheels and domed it and
polish it up on the felt pad on the other side of the lapidary equipment.
I took the Thundercats embled then domed that into the contour of the red glass stone.

After completing the gem stone and drilling
the hole through it
we'd soldered a chicago screw onto the back of the
Thundercats emblem and there will be a screw
help that holds everything together.

The blade is now ground and ready for
hardening and the heat treating oven.

I've been refining all the edges on the
components for the hilt, and we start tig

welding them together. Make it a
homogeneous piece before we weld
that part onto the sword.
This sword is a super elaborate build.

There's probably over fifty or sixty
components on it: individual stones, little

fittings on the hilt, with different
segments on the grip and pommel.

It's been a lot of work putting together, but i'm
really pleased with the final outcome.
All the pieces are together and Thundercats Sword of Omens is complete.
Step aside Lion-O, let a real king take a swing.
Thanks for watching Man at Arms. Be sure to subscribe. next.
Tell me in the comments which weapon you'd like to see next.

title: Sword of Omens (Thundercats) - MAN AT ARMS
